Package com.rubynaxela.kyanite.game.assets

Class TextureAtlas

java.lang.Object
com.rubynaxela.kyanite.game.assets.TextureAtlas
All Implemented Interfaces:
Asset
public class TextureAtlas extends Object implements Asset
This class is designed to create many textures from a single image file. Sample usage: 
new TextureAtlas("chocolate_stages.png").get(32, 0, 16, 16)
The above code will create from the specified file a 16px by 16px Texture, of which the top left corner will correspond to the (32,0) point in the image.

      Parameters:

      startY - the Y-coordinate of the start point
      endX - the X-coordinate of the end point
      endY - the Y-coordinate of the end point
      Returns:
      a Texture containing image within the bounds of a rectangle of the specified coordinates

      public Texture getRect(int x, int y, int width, int height)
      Creates a Texture containing the image within the bounds of a rectangle of the specified origin coordinates (the top-left corner) and size.
      Parameters:
      x - the X-coordinate of the start point
      y - the Y-coordinate of the start point
      width - the width of the texture
      height - the height of the texture
      Returns:
      a Texture containing image within the bounds of a rectangle of the specified origin and size

    • getMatrix

      public Texture[][] getMatrix(int startX, int startY, int width, int height, int countX, int countY)
      Creates a 2D array of textures from this atlas, starting from the specified coordinates of the image file. All textures are the same size. Example usage:
       Texture[][] smoke = assets.get<TextureAtlas>("particle.smoke")
                           .getMatrix(16, 16, 8, 2);
 smoke[3][1].apply(this);
      The above code will create an 8 columns by 2 rows 2D array of 16x16 textures and apply the fourth texture from the second row to the object that ran this code.
      Parameters:
      startX - x-coordindate of the texture atlas starting point
      startY - y-coordindate of the texture atlas starting point
      width - a single texture width
      height - a single texture height
      countX - the number of textures in a row
      countY - the number of textures in a column
      Returns:
      a 2D array of textures from this atlas

    • getMatrix

      public Texture[][] getMatrix(int width, int height, int countX, int countY)
      Creates a 2D array of textures from this atlas, starting from the top-left corner of the image file. All textures are the same size. Example usage:
       Texture[][] smoke = assets.get<TextureAtlas>("particle.smoke")
                           .getMatrix(16, 16, 8, 2);
 smoke[3][1].apply(this);
      The above code will create an 8 columns by 2 rows 2D array of 16x16 textures and apply the fourth texture from the second row to the object that ran this code.
      Parameters:
      width - a single texture width
      height - a single texture height
      countX - the number of textures in a row
      countY - the number of textures in a column
      Returns:
      a 2D array of textures from this atlas

    • getRow

      public Texture[] getRow(int startX, int startY, int width, int height, int count)
      Creates a row of textures from this atlas, starting from the specified coordinates of the image file. All textures are the same size. Example usage:
       Texture[] smoke = assets.get<TextureAtlas>("particle.smoke")
                         .getRow(16, 16, 8);
 smoke[3].apply(this);
      The above code will create an array of 8 16x16 textures and apply the fourth one to the object that ran this code.
      Parameters:
      width - a single texture width
      height - a single texture height
      count - the number of textures
      Returns:
      an array of textures from this atlas

    • getRow

      public Texture[] getRow(int width, int height, int count)
      Creates a row of textures from this atlas, starting from the top-left corner of the image file. All textures are the same size. Example usage:
       Texture[] smoke = assets.get<TextureAtlas>("particle.smoke")
                         .getRow(16, 16, 8);
 smoke[3].apply(this);
      The above code will create an array of 8 16x16 textures and apply the fourth one to the object that ran this code.
      Parameters:
      width - a single texture width
      height - a single texture height
      count - the number of textures
      Returns:
      an array of textures from this atlas
